body:
I need a full backtrace. 

> On Oct 8, 2019, at 09:39, OrrYakobi <notifications@github.com> wrote:
> 
> Ôªø
> I am using Ruby 2.5.6, Rails 5.1.7, and Sidekiq 6.0.1
> 
> The following argument error, ArgumentError Job 'at' must be a Numeric timestamp, is occurring at vendor/bundle/ruby/2.5.0/gems/sidekiq-6.0.1/lib/sidekiq/client.rb:225
> 
> For convenience, here's the line that is causing the issue.
> raise(ArgumentError, "Job 'at' must be a Numeric timestamp") if item.key?("at") && !item["at"].is_a?(Numeric)
> 
> ‚Äî
> You are receiving this because you are subscribed to this thread.
> Reply to this email directly, view it on GitHub, or mute the thread.

```
vendor/bundle/ruby/2.5.0/gems/sidekiq-6.0.1/lib/sidekiq/client.rb:225:in `normalize_item': Job 'at' must be a Numeric timestamp (ArgumentError)
    from vendor/bundle/ruby/2.5.0/gems/sidekiq-6.0.1/lib/sidekiq/client.rb:70:in `push'
    from vendor/bundle/ruby/2.5.0/gems/sidekiq-6.0.1/lib/sidekiq/client.rb:136:in `push'
    from vendor/bundle/ruby/2.5.0/gems/sidekiq-6.0.1/lib/sidekiq/scheduled.rb:27:in `block (3 levels) in enqueue_jobs'
    from vendor/bundle/ruby/2.5.0/gems/sidekiq-6.0.1/lib/sidekiq/scheduled.rb:22:in `each'
    from vendor/bundle/ruby/2.5.0/gems/sidekiq-6.0.1/lib/sidekiq/scheduled.rb:22:in `block (2 levels) in enqueue_jobs'
    from vendor/bundle/ruby/2.5.0/gems/sidekiq-6.0.1/lib/sidekiq/scheduled.rb:16:in `each'

    from vendor/bundle/ruby/2.5.0/gems/sidekiq-6.0.1/lib/sidekiq.rb:97:in `block in redis'
    from vendor/bundle/ruby/2.5.0/gems/connection_pool-2.2.2/lib/connection_pool.rb:65:in `block (2 levels) in with'
    from vendor/bundle/ruby/2.5.0/gems/connection_pool-2.2.2/lib/connection_pool.rb:64:in `handle_interrupt'
    from vendor/bundle/ruby/2.5.0/gems/connection_pool-2.2.2/lib/connection_pool.rb:64:in `block in with'
    from vendor/bundle/ruby/2.5.0/gems/connection_pool-2.2.2/lib/connection_pool.rb:61:in `handle_interrupt'
    from vendor/bundle/ruby/2.5.0/gems/connection_pool-2.2.2/lib/connection_pool.rb:61:in `with'
    from vendor/bundle/ruby/2.5.0/gems/sidekiq-6.0.1/lib/sidekiq.rb:94:in `redis'
    from vendor/bundle/ruby/2.5.0/gems/sidekiq-6.0.1/lib/sidekiq/scheduled.rb:15:in `enqueue_jobs'
    from vendor/bundle/ruby/2.5.0/gems/sidekiq-6.0.1/lib/sidekiq/scheduled.rb:78:in `enqueue'
    from vendor/bundle/ruby/2.5.0/gems/sidekiq-6.0.1/lib/sidekiq/scheduled.rb:70:in `block in start'

    from vendor/bundle/ruby/2.5.0/gems/sidekiq-6.0.1/lib/sidekiq/util.rb:26:in `block in safe_thread'
```

Unfortunately that doesn‚Äôt tell me much. You‚Äôll need to show me how you are calling perform_in for that job. Somehow bad job data is getting scheduled.

From a high level, what I am doing is this: 

```
array_of_json.in_goups_of(10).each_with_index do |json_group, index|
  Worker.perform_in(index.minutes, json_group)
end

```

would calling 0.minutes pose an issue?
@OrrYakobi  Can you provide a minimal reproducible test script, which shows a problem?

> @OrrYakobi Can you provide a minimal reproducible test script, which shows a problem?

```
hashes = (1..25).map { |i| {value: i} }

hashes.in_groups_of(10, false).each_with_index do |hash_group, index|
  PutsWorker.perform_in(index.minutes, hash_group)
end


class PutsWorker 
  include Sidekiq::Worker
  
  def perform(hash_group)
    puts hash_group.pluck(hash_group[:value]).join(",")
  end
end
```

NOTE: Downgraded to Sidekiq 6.0.0 and problem stopped

```
$ bundle exec rails c
Loading development environment (Rails 6.0.0)
irb(main):001:0> hashes = (1..25).map { |i| {value: i} }
=> [{:value=>1}, {:value=>2}, {:value=>3}, {:value=>4}, {:value=>5}, {:value=>6}, {:value=>7}, {:value=>8}, {:value=>9}, {:value=>10}, {:value=>11}, {:value=>12}, {:value=>13}, {:value=>14}, {:value=>15}, {:value=>16}, {:value=>17}, {:value=>18}, {:value=>19}, {:value=>20}, {:value=>21}, {:value=>22}, {:value=>23}, {:value=>24}, {:value=>25}]
irb(main):002:0> 
irb(main):003:0> hashes.in_groups_of(10, false).each_with_index do |hash_group, index|
irb(main):004:1*   PutsWorker.perform_in(index.minutes, hash_group)
irb(main):005:1> end
Traceback (most recent call last):
        4: from (irb):3
        3: from (irb):3:in `each_with_index'
        2: from (irb):3:in `each'
        1: from (irb):4:in `block in irb_binding'
NameError (uninitialized constant PutsWorker)
Did you mean?  EmptyWorker
```

Please give me an actual working script to reproduce the problem.
(Yes, I flipped the code to fix that problem.  It still did not reproduce the issue.)

Here's a script that reproduces the same problem for `push_bulk`:
https://github.com/pharmaceutics/sidekiq_601_test

The worker works fine on the first try, but raises `Job 'at' must be a Numeric timestamp` on retry.

First issue is that client.rb line 103 always includes an `at` key, even when the jobs are not being scheduled.

```ruby
copy = normed.merge("args" => args, "jid" => SecureRandom.hex(12), "at" => single_at, "enqueued_at" => Time.now.to_f)
```
Thank you @pharmaceutics, your script allowed me to reproduce, debug and verify this fix. üëçüèº
